snippet: Australia has had no killings of five or more since a 1996 rampage spurred a tightening of laws. Other forms of gun violence have fallen as well.
abstract: Studies have shown that Australia's sweeping gun restrictions, enacted in 1996 after gunman massacred 35 people, have led to sharp reduction in gun violence; while Australia is frequently mentioned as example in United States for type of gun control legislation US should pursue, America has never tried national gun buyback program.

byline.original: By AUSTIN RAMZY, MICHELLE INNIS and PATRICK BOEHLER
byline.contributor: Austin Ramzy and Patrick Boehler reported from Hong Kong, and Michelle Innis from Sydney, Australia.

lead_paragraph: Australia has had no killings of five or more since a 1996 rampage spurred a tightening of laws. Other forms of gun violence have fallen as well.

headline.main: How a Conservative-Led Australia Ended Mass Killings
headline.print_headline: A Deterrent to Mass Killings in Australia
